item.title: National Liberation Front
item.dc:creator: SSgt. Gibson
item.description:
National Liberation Front



The National Liberation Front of Southern Vietnam, nicknamed by their adversaries "Viet Cong", was one of the main combatants of the Vietnam War, making it a unique piece of the conflict through its extensive use of guerilla warfare, nighttime operations, and infiltration. First declared a sovereign group in the later part of 1960 while the war had already been raging for years, the fighting elements of what would eventually become the NLF were already present in South Vietnam years earlier.

The Viet Cong's guerrilla tactics, complex tunnel systems, the operations they took part in, and appreciation of nature are often points of discussion when considering their participation in the hostilities. However, there are some aspects of the National Liberation Front which are rarely touched upon; the context of their creation and their fate once the war was over and Vietnam was reunited.

Birth of the Liberation Front

Failed military coups, peasant uprisings, and armed religious sects in the years leading to 1960 were already doing much to destabilize South Vietnam. While some of these groups were successful in dismantling the presence of the government's police and military within the regions they had surged in, the lack of support and no steady supply line meant it was a matter of time before they had to abandon their newly obtained territory and go underground again to avoid direct conflict with the Army of the Republic.

The National Liberation Front was created to centralize these many insurgent groups within South Vietnam, and not only aid them with the supplies that came from North Vietnam through the Ho Chi Minh Trail but also guide them on military campaigns. These groups were varied in origin, their background, members, the nature of their dissent, their ethnicity, religious beliefs, and even their plans for Vietnam if it were to be once again united. The main groups were those who had suffered direct suppression by South Vietnam's government and some of those who had already supported Vietnam against France during the First Indochina War. Political groups, religious sects, and other social organizations, many of which had already clashed with South Vietnam's secret police force, were the groups that formed the political parties that would, in 1960, form a Central Committee and unite these groups into one organization. The newly formed NLF would soon carry on to join North Vietnam against the Southern forces, now relying on supplies coming from the North through the Ho Chi Minh trail.

Before the First Indochina War, the Ho Chi Minh trail was an unnamed, unrefined trade line that had been in use in the region for centuries, but had since been improved for military use during wartime. By 1959, one year before the proper creation of the NLF, the People's Army of North Vietnam 559th Transportation Group had already been tasked with maintaining and improving the trail to supply insurgents within South Vietnam, turning it into the network of supply lines that would be vital to the NLF's success, transporting tonnes of supplies and thousands of men to the south.

The National Liberation Front of Southern Vietnam, what had once been a variety of motivated but fickle and undersupplied insurgent groups within South Vietnam's borders, now was a centralized group, with an intricate supply line providing them with much-needed resources coming from North Vietnam. The Viet Cong was now prepared to make their debut on the battlefields of the Vietnam War.

Victory and Defeat in the South

As the war continued, in June 1969 the political leadership of the NLF formed the Provisional Revolutionary Government of the Republic of South Vietnam, with the intent of helping the Viet Cong obtain international stature. The PRG was formed from the political entities already within the Front, and other south Vietnamese political elements supportive of their cause. Their declared intent was to advance the interests of the South Vietnamese people and provide the Liberation Front with a governmental structure. Settled near the Cambodian border, the PRG initiated organizing its negotiations for eventual reunification. However, after the US and South Vietnamese forces launched the Cambodian campaign, the PRG suffered losses, and the replacements sent from North Vietnam were clashing with the more neutral parties, causing political turmoil within the PRG ranks. When complaints sent to the North Vietnamese government were dismissed, it became clear to NLF and PRG leadership that the nationalists and less revolutionary volunteers who once united to create the Liberation Front were now being cast aside in favor of those determined on advancing North Vietnam's interests.

The military organization of the Front was similar to its political segment, as the NLF forces suffered casualties, they were replenished by North Vietnamese men, steadily replacing the southerners within the military organization. This reached a peak after the Tet Offensive where, by the estimation of the PAVN and Viet Cong, forty thousand Viet Cong were killed, with more than sixty thousand being injured. NLF leaders noted that units that were once dominated by southerners had been replaced by northerners years before the fall of Saigon. This solidifies the loss of unity inside the groups that were created within the borders of South Vietnam, intending to extend the interests of the South Vietnamese people against a government they believed was ruling not for its people.

After the fall of Saigon on the 30th of April 1975, the Provisional Government of the Republic of South Vietnam assumed power in the South and participated in the reunification of Vietnam. The North Vietnamese leadership swiftly decided to dissolve the PRG after the reunification was completed. North and South now merged into the Socialist Republic of Vietnam in July 1976, the PRG was dissolved, and the National Liberation Front soon followed a comparable fate, being merged with the Vietnamese Fatherland Front in February 1977.

The National Liberation Front of Southern Vietnam succeeded in its fight against the South Vietnamese government and their American allies, but the southern nationalists were replaced by men from the north as the war went on. This would eventually be the main cause of North Vietnam having sole authority over the now reunified nation.

Written by PFC de Freitas
Edited by T5 Evarts and PFC Mrzena

item.title: Merrill's Marauders
item.dc:creator: SSgt. Gibson
item.description:
5307th Composite Unit


"Merrill's Marauders"

5307th Composite Unit, nicknamed "Merrill's Marauders'' after the units commander and referred to in operation by codename “Galahad”, was an all volunteer regiment composed of soldiers and officers from the jungle trained Caribbean Defense Command, Army Ground Forces in continental United States, veterans from South Pacific Command, and even soldiers from military prisons who were offered their freedom in exchange for service. In all, the unit numbered 2,997 men. This unit, on top of their specialized training, received a generous arsenal of various US Army weaponry that favored mobility. The unit also had 700 animals largely composed of horses and mules to transport supplies through the jungle terrain. Finally, unlike other units in the Burma Campaign that were under British command and answered to Admiral Lord Mountbatten, the Deputy Supreme Commander of South East Asia, Merrill's Marauders answered to Deputy Supreme Commander General Stilwell of Northern Combat Area. This specialized unit was tasked with penetrating deep behind Imperial Japanese lines during World War II to conduct guerilla warfare during the Burma Campaign, supporting the Republic of China against Imperial Japan with British and American aid.

The unit's nickname "Merrill's Marauders" originated when General Stilwell appointed Brigadier General Frank Merrill to lead the unit, and during their tour, Time News correspondent James Shepley was thinking of a catchy name for the unit as 5307th Composite Unit didn't quite captivate the public image. So he came up with "Merrill's Marauders" and the name stuck ever since then. The commander, Brigadier General Merrill, was previously a Staff Sergeant in the Engineering Corp where he was able to get an appointment to West Point. He was also a military attaché in Tokyo where he studied Japanese, before joining General Douglas MacArthur's Staff as an intelligence officer. By the end of the war, Frank Merrill was a Colonel, however, he retired from service as a Major General.Remarkably, Frank Merrill became a Brigadier General only a month before his fortieth birthday, making him one of the youngest generals since the Civil War. His accolades include, Distinguished Service Medal, Legion of Merit, Bronze Star, and a Purple Heart on top of being inducted into the US Army Ranger Hall of Fame.

Merrill Marauders' successes came largely from their jungle training, experienced NCO and officer corps, and understanding the limitations of their arsenal. Such as the fact that the unit lacked a heavy weapons company, and thus relied heavily on flexibility and surprise to outfight the Imperial Japanese forces; as every single soldier within the regiment had automatic weapons. However, a little known secret among the unit's success was the integration of Japanese-American soldiers from the Military Intelligence Service who acted as translators for the unit. Many of these translators would go on to become US Army Rangers and get inducted into both the Military Intelligence Hall of Fame and the US Army Ranger Hall of Fame. It should be noted that the conditions these soldiers faced were brutal, as weight was critical for the Marauders; they relied on jungle rations to stay dry, light weight, and give a large pool of calories to the exhausted men. However, because they were discontinued due to cost, the unit relied on K rations as an alternative which was largely unpopular among the men in terms of taste, so would often trade cigarettes with the allied forces for food.

Despite the limitations that the unit faced with firepower, and the constant struggles of jungle warfare such as sunbathing to fight off fungal skin infections, Merrill's Marauders inflicted heavy casualties against Japanese Imperial Forces- in one battle inflicting 400 casualties while suffering 57 KIA, 302 wounded, and 379 incapacitated due to illness or exhaustion. On their final mission to capture Myitkyina, Marauders suffered 272 KIA, 955 wounded, 980 evacuated due to illness and disease while inflicting over 3,800 KIA and 187 POW of the Imperial Japanese forces on their last mission. The unit would eventually capture Myitkyina, however, only 200 of the original Marauders were present. By the time the unit was disbanded, only 130 combat effective enlisted men and officers out of the original 2,997 men would be present. Out of the entire regiment, only two individuals were never hospitalized for wounds or major illness.

The unit’s dedication and tenacity would leave a long lasting legacy within the United States military, with the 75th Ranger Regiment inheriting their legacy and paying homage to Merrill's Marauders as they set the foundation to how a light infantry unit would operate and is still used to this very day by various special operation units. The Marauders’ actions would not go unnoticed, as the unit holds the rare distinction of every single member having earned the Bronze Star for their actions, and the unit as a whole being awarded Distinguished Unit Citation and the Congressional Gold Medal. Many of the marauders would later be inducted into Army Ranger Hall of Fame and/or Military Intelligence Hall of Fame. Notably, David Richardson, the most decorated soldier-journalist of World War II was a Marauder, having earned two Bronze Stars, Legion of Merit, and was eligible for the Purple Heart but refused treatment in favor of returning to the action. As of December 31, 2020 seven Marauders are still alive.

Written by Cpl. Dawdy
Edited by Cpl. Tilley and PFC Mrzena

item.title: 2020 Year in Review
item.dc:creator: SSgt. Gibson
item.description:
2020 was quite the year for all of us, especially in regards to the 29th. This was a year filled once again with events and expansion, possibly to a level that has not been seen in quite some time.

As with 2019, we had another great start to the year beginning with one of the better events that a member of the 29th can participate in: OCS Scrims. 2Lt. Stray of CP2, 2Lt. Brenholen of DP3, and 2Lt. Dahl, formerly of EP4, all completed their OCS Scrims and were commissioned to the rank of Second Lieutenant. Additionally, the OCS Scrims provided an opportunity for medals to be earned with one Bronze Star being awarded for actions during these events.

Unfortunately, world events took a negative turn, and the traditional April Fools joke had to be postponed. Taking its place was a unit-wide weapons pass for the month of April, giving members the opportunity to use that extra time on their hands to have a little extra fun on 29th servers.
A big theme in 2020 was the unofficial scrimmages with outside units that Charlie and Easy Company participated in. These events brought the opportunity for competitive gameplay without the intense preparations that scrims bring. Members of many of these events were awarded an Armed Forces Expeditionary Medal.

Easy Company also got busy this year with their Operations Corps planning and hosting many public scrimmages that many outside units attended. These Pub Scrims introduced many other units to 29th-type drills and even led to some of those units being opponents in official scrims.



2020 was quite the year for official scrims in the unit, with every company deploying a platoon at least once. First was EP3 being deployed to fight the Canadian Forces in what was ultimately a victory. DP1 followed up next with a scrim against the 1st Cavalry in August in what was also a total victory. Next came DP3 in September with their victory over Phoenix Gaming. The fourth scrim of 2020 went to EP4 who tied 1-1 with Squad Ops in a hard fought deployment. The final scrim of the year went to Charlie Company, who participated in a large scale coalition fight in which they won their attack.

1Lt. Nelson had the following to say about 2020 for Charlie Company:

"Long story short, we had a very eventful year, and 2021 is looking to be even more so. Morale is high, and our mix of old-timers and newer folks makes for a fantastic experience all around. I can't emphasize enough how great "Friday Night Fights" has been for our ability to network with other realism units and how great of an opportunity it provides to train leadership at all levels in combat."

– 1Lt. Nelson, Charlie Company Commanding Officer



While fighting other units is exciting and a lot of work, that wasn’t enough for Charlie and Easy Companies. Charlie followed in the footsteps of Dog and Easy Companies with their own Charlie Battle of the Squads in which CP1S3 were the victors. Easy Company changed it up. Rather than doing a Battle of the Squads, they did Battle of the Platoons, where every platoon fought each other and EP3 came out on top as the top platoon of Easy in 2020.

We wrapped up this incredibly busy year the way we began it, with another round of OCS Scrims, again featuring members of each Company. 2Lt. Drake of CP1, 2Lt. Griffin of DP1, 2Lt. Deb of DP2, and 2Lt. Furie of EP2 all completed scrims of their own and were commissioned to Second Lieutenant. Of course these promotions were accompanied with many other promotions to Company and Platoon Headquarters. 1Lt. Nelson, 1Lt. Ochs, and TSgt. Robles were all promoted to Company HQ, and FSgt. Dethfield became Senior NCO of Easy Company. Along with the seven Second Lieutenants commissioned this year, SSgt. Vandewalle of CP2, Sgt. Gibson of EP3, SSgt. Newton of EP4, and SSgt. Crane of EP5 were all promoted to Platoon Sergeant.

One of the primary causes for the promotions of new leadership is due to the expansion of the companies. Dog Company added DP2S4 and DP3S4 while Easy Company opened EP5 in a new time zone for the unit, PST.

Captain Fritz had the following to say about 2020 for Easy Company:

"While 2020 was an unmitigated disaster, I’ll look back at it with fondness. Easy Company and the 29th as a whole achieved so much during the downtime of the various national and local lockdowns provided. From growing numbers and new platoon expansions; to OCS Scrims, Pub Scrims, and official deployments, and even the first-ever Battle of the Platoons, I can say truthfully that this was by far the most exciting year in my tenure here. 2020 showed me, and I hope to all of you, what we can achieve as a unit. While I hope 2021 is a far more stable year, rest assured that we will keep pushing things to new heights so that we can all enjoy an even better 29th ID. Ever Forward!"

– Cpt. Fritz, Easy Company Commanding Officer



It goes without saying that 2020 was very busy, and there are no signs of the unit slowing down in 2021. The dedication that everyone shows to attending drills, along with the hard work that staff, SLT, Squad, Platoon, Company, and Battalion leadership put in to the unit make this one of the most, if not the most premier realism units out there.

"Looking back at 2020, I'm amazed at how full the unit feels. Thanks to the nonstop action of our unit's recruiters, we are pushing very close to the 500 member mark. That is truly historic. In addition to the fullness of our roster, our senior officers have been hard at work fostering numerous Officer Candidate School cadres to develop junior officers allowing for needed expansion. Not only did we have some very nerve-wracking OCS Scrimmages, but the unit also fielded multiple platoons in Official Scrimmages against other units. This, in turn, has led to numerous badges, awards, and bragging rights for many across our ranks. One more "Congratulations!" to those who represented the unit on the ultimate stage, we're proud of the effort and professionalism you achieved.

We've had some other members answer the call to higher leadership in 2020 and I want to thank them for their efforts and service to the Battalion and their Companies. Special thanks to 1Lt. Nelson, 1Lt. Ochs, and TSgt. Robles. Your ranks below and this Battalion as a whole would not be the same without you gents and Battalion Headquarters thanks you!

Looking ahead to 2021, I hope to see continued growth amongst the ranks, from AIT's to SLT to OCS and beyond. The work each and every one of you put in is truly inspiring and Battalion Headquarters is entirely confident that big things are coming because of those efforts. Keep pushing yourselves, your squad, and those around you, together we embody our motto of "Ever Forward!". Happy New Year and 29th, Let's GO!"

– Lt. Col. Wheatley , Battalion Commander



Written by Sgt. Gibson
Edited by Cpl. J. Lee

item.title: THE REAL 29TH - THE BATTLE OF SAINT-LÔ
item.dc:creator: SSgt. Gibson
item.description:
THE REAL 29th - THE BATTLE OF SAINT-LÔ

Most people exposed to Anglophone media know about the Normandy landings (Operation Neptune), in which the 29th Infantry Division (ID) took part. People living in the early 21st century know of the famous movies such as “Saving Private Ryan” which depicted the landings of the 29th at Omaha beach. On June 6, 1944, the 116th "Ever Forward" Regiment of the 29th ID, was indeed assigned to the first wave on four sectors of Omaha, intended to support the 1st Infantry Division “Big Red One”. Of it’s 3100 men, the 116th Regiment took 900 casualties. By the 7th of June, the rest of the 29th had landed and by the 9th, Omaha Beach was secure and the division took Insigny-sur-mer. However, few know of the subsequent battles the 29th fought after Normandy, unless you actually read about it or if you played Company of Heroes 1. This article serves as a brief account of the 29th taking Saint-Lô in July 1944.

THE 29th ID AFTER D-DAY IN JUNE 1944

In the middle of 1944, the 29th ID was composed of 3 infantry regiments (115th, 116th, 175th), supported by 4 Field Artillery Battalions (105mm guns), and one support battalion each of combat engineers, medical, mechanized reconnaissance, signals, and others. This was the standard organization for non-elite U.S army divisions. By late June, the 29th ID’s effective strength was around 12,000, since it had suffered more than 1000 casualties on D-Day and was considered understrength. However, after two weeks of reorganization and regroup, on July 14th, the 29th Division was reassigned to XIX Corps (also consisting the 30th ID and 35th ID) with the task of leading the assault towards Saint-Lô. Located roughly 25 miles to the Southwest of Omaha, the division began its march along the hedgerow filled terrain to the city.

THE STRATEGIC OBJECTIVE OF SAINT-LÔ

Saint-Lô was a large strategic objective, chosen alongside Carentan and Caen by SHAEF (Supreme Headquarters, Allied Expeditionary Force) for obvious reasons. With a population of 11,000, Saint-Lô sat on low ground surrounded by hills, with large arterial roads that connected it to other major ports and roads towards Bayeux, an important staging ground for the allied push further into France and Belgium. Since D-Day, St-Lô had already been under heavy allied bombing which destroyed most of the city and dispersed the local population (with an unknown number of civilian casualties). This bombing campaign was to prevent German supplies and reinforcements from moving into the allied invasion zone by rail or road. The ground offensive for St. Lô was planned in late June and involved 12 Allied divisions in 4 Corps on a 12 mile front, against a hodgepodge of German troops that retreated from Normandy, as well as fresh elite troops that were stationed deeper in Normandy. The Divisional Commander of the 29th ID, Maj.Gen Gerhardt, was assigned a sector stretching a few miles. Directly facing the 29th and guarding the town and surrounding area were elements of the 352. Infanterie Division and the elite 3. Fallschirmjägerdivision (3. FSJg). In all, an estimated 10-15,000 German troops were in the AO, but the actual number remains unknown.

THE 116TH AND THE BOCAGES

On July 11th, the 29th was given orders to commence the attack. P-47 Thunderbolts were called to strafe the hedgerows surrounding the city. 1st Battalion of 116th (our unit’s real life counterpart) was surrounded as it had unwittingly crossed too far ahead, and had become encircled for 2 days before being relieved by elements of the 115th. This mishap led to numerous friendly fire incidents from aerial bombardment, resulting in more than 100 casualties for the 116th. Strategic locations such as hills and river crossings were pre-marked by German artillery and continuously bombarded.

THE 3. FALLSCHIRMJÄGERDIVISION

Both German and American sources indicate clearly that it was the 3.FSJg that inflicted the most casualties on the 29th at St-Lô. 29th Veterans noted that the 3.FSJg preferred to attack suddenly at night and from all sides. 1/115th received a night attack which its commander described as “beautifully executed and planned”; a barrage of precise 88mm, Nebelwerfer and 105mm shells which led to its outposts becoming overrun. This parachute unit was veteran and composed entirely of very young volunteers. They had gone through the most intense training the Luftwaffe had to offer, and had previously fought at Crete in 1941. Moreover, it was much better equipped than the soldiers of the 29th. Along with SS Panzer detachments, it was much more heavily equipped, had more mortars, and was 30% larger than the 29th ID. Each company in the 3.FSJg had 20 machineguns and 43 SMGs, but each company in the 29th ID only had 2 .30 cal guns and 9 BARs. Knowing that St-Lô was being bombarded, it had entrenched itself over the hedgerows in a wide area. They also mined the entirety of the roads facing the 29th and camouflaged StuG IIIs in ditches, making them almost invulnerable to aerial attack. One battalion commander of the 29th said: "Those Germans are the best damned soldiers I ever saw. They're smart and they don't know what 'fear' means. They come in and they keep coming until they get their job done or you kill 'em."

From July 17th, it was clear to XIX Corps HQ that the 29th had become bogged down in the hedgerows due to the terrain of Normandy and the elite German troops, and famously lost one battalion commander from mortar fire; Major Thomas Howie. Major General Gerhardt, the divisional commander, famously put Major Howie’s flag draped body on a jeep and drove into the city, calling the dead Major “the Major of St-Lô”. On the 17th, the 29th entered St-Lô in force and witnessed a destroyed city with Germans entrenched in urban terrain, facing snipers and mines which heavily slowed the advance and resorted the commander to call aerial bombing to level the city. As such, the city was virtually destroyed. By July 19th, the city had been taken by the 29th, but not before the division tallied a very high amount of casualties- twice as much as the 82nd or 101st Airborne Division. At this point, the 116th regiment alone had suffered 2516 casualties since June 7th (the regiment had landed on D-Day with 3100 men), while the total losses of the division amounted to 3706. Due to the incredibly high amount of casualties, on July 20th, the 29th was called back to the reserve line and replaced by the 35th ID.

THE 29th AFTER ST-LÔ

After St-Lô, the 29th was relieved and redeployed to Vire, capturing the city by August 7th during Operation Cobra (an armor led assault deep into France to encircle the Germans). It was then assigned to Brest, and later took part in the invasion of the Ruhr area of Germany. The 29th ID was famous not only because of the Normandy landings, but also because it had a relatively high casualty rate (20,600 casualties) from June 1944 to May 1945 (more than 200% of its strength in just 242 days of combat). From the episode of St-Lô, it is clear that the 29th was neither ready nor well-equipped to face the elite 3.FSJg, but nevertheless got the job done due to numerous other units in the operation as well as armor and air support. Some historians have blamed the unit’s commander, Gerhardt for recklessness which led to demoralization in the unit, but that shall be covered in another story.

Written by Cpl. Tan
Edited by Cpl. Tilley and PFC Mrzena

item.title: The Real 29th: Major Thomas Dry Howie
item.dc:creator: SSgt. Gibson
item.description:
The Real 29th: Major Thomas Dry Howie

"The Major of St. Lo"


Major Thomas Howie was the Battalion Commander of the 116th Infantry Regiment during the Battle of Normandy in World War II. During his service, he proved to be an exemplary leader and a soldier of the 29th Infantry Division, whom forever would be immortalized as "The Major of St. Lo" in his critical last efforts in capturing the city from German occupation.

Major Howie was born in Abbeville, South Carolina in 1908 as the fifth of seven children. He would later attend The Military College of South Carolina, more popularly known as "The Citadel", where he majored in English. He was assigned to Charlie Cadet Company and obtained the rank of Cadet Corporal. He was also voted "Most Versatile, Popular, and Best All Around" by his class. After graduating, he taught English at Stauton Military Academy, before accepting a commission into the Virginia National Guard in 1932. During his tenure in Stauton, he would meet and marry Elizabeth Payne; together, they had a daughter named Sally in 1938.


Major Thomas Howie with his wife Elizabeth Payne

Major Howie entered active service when the 29th Infantry Division was federalized in 1941. He received training in Maryland, Florida, and North Carolina, before being moved to the United Kingdom in preparation for D-Day, where his unit also received additional intensive training for Omaha Beach. Major Howie was assigned to command 3rd Battalion in the next coming days. After the initial invasion of Omaha Beach, Major Howie was tasked with rescuing 2nd Battalion, who'd become surrounded with very little food and ammunition. Under his leadership, Major Howie managed to break through the German lines using bayonets and grenades in fewer than two hours despite his battalion being at half strength. Major Howie was also personally credited with eliminating two enemy machine gun nests single handedly. After resupplying 2nd Battalion to defend their position, Major Howie reported to Major General Charles Gerhardt, the Division Commander, that the 2nd were "too cut up" and planned to use his 3rd Battalion to take St. Lo, saying "Yes, we can do it" and "See you in St. Lo!". Unfortunately, moments later in the attack, Major Howie was killed by shrapnel from a mortar attack.


"See you in St. Lo!" By Larry Selman

The next day, 3rd Battalion entered St. Lo with Major Howie's body on a hood of a jeep draped over by an American flag. Under orders of Major General Gerhardt, Major Howie was to be the first American to enter town. His body was placed at the rubbles of St. Croix Cathedral, giving both soldiers and civilians the opportunity to pay their respects to the fallen Major. The photo of Major Howie's flag-draped body was widely circulated in the United States by the New York Times, becoming one of the most iconic pictures of the war of American sacrifice in the Western Theater. However, due to wartime security, Major Howie's name couldn't be revealed. It was only announced that the body was a major of the United States Army which led to his immortalization as "The Major of St. Lo". His body was buried in Normandy American Cemetery.


New York Times' Picture of "The Major of St. Lo"

Major Thomas Howie was awarded the Silver Star, Bronze Star, Purple Heart, Presidential Unit Citation, Legion of Honor (Chevalier), and the French Croix de Guerre. Several buildings and a statue were made in his honor at The Citadel, Stauton Military Academy, several ROTC buildings, and Mary Baldwin College. He is also enshrined in the South Carolina Hall of Fame. In his honor, a granite monument at his hometown of Abbeville is escribed "Dead in France, Deathless in Fame".

Written by Cpl. Dawdy
Edited by Sgt. Gibson & Cpl. J. Lee

item.title: EP4 Scrim Summary
item.dc:creator: SSgt. Gibson
item.description:
EP4 Scrim



I had been working in Signal Corps searching around the Squad community for scrim opponents for about a year, and from day one, I hoped we could arrange a scrim with the SquadOps community. They are by far the longest standing one-life group in Squad besides the 29th, so I saw them as our best chance for a real tough fight. Sadly, I was unable to get anything to come to fruition with them. Fast forward a year later and a few scrims down the line, and Sgt. Furie was able to secure this scrim with them with relative ease. Once I heard the news that EP4 would finally have our scrim and it would be against what I perceived as the toughest challenge out there, and on my favorite map of Gorodok no less, I was pretty ecstatic. The scenario itself reminded me somewhat of the EP3 scenario with large portions of the map open to the defenders as well as a lot of foliage and small villages for the attackers to contend with.



The infamous month of scrim prep began shortly after the announcement was made to the company, and EP4 got right to work on picking the area apart and coming up with a plan to overcome the river crossing as well as how to best approach the objectives in the double bunkers area. Initially, we probed each approach individually to see the merits and downfalls of each one. We quickly came to the realization that the north, west, and direct south approaches took us deep into enemy territory where we could get surrounded as the round went on due the forests and hills in those locations giving the defenders plentiful amounts of concealment. This is something EP3 had to deal with as well in their scrim, which they did successfully by taking an approach that eliminated as much unseeable, or untraversable area for the defenders as possible.


In order for EP4 to implement a similar idea, 2Lt. Dahl and I decided to try and use the large river, marking the movement restrictions for the defenders, as a way to protect our flanks through much of our approach. By attacking from the east and southeast, we were able to protect our sides and rear for much of the round until we approached the objective itself. In our preparation, this plan immediately showed more promise than the other approaches as we could force our enemy to fight us head on. However, as the weeks progressed and our plan became more concrete, we began to run into issues as the opfor 29th members we were practicing against began to find ways to challenge and counter our plan. Initially, this was a benefit as we could see what our plan’s weaknesses were. A few changes needed to be made in order to get around these weaknesses and they were implemented pretty successfully. The first major change came from T/5 Perez-Pantoja, who discovered a wonderful location for the Bradley to fire upon the two northern objectives from a cliff on the NE on our side of the river. This worked beautifully and it meant that we only had to destroy the 2 southern objectives by hand. The second biggest change was that EP4S3 needed to be sent across the river a bit early in the north to clear out a cliffside that looked down the length of the river that the rest of our team needed to cross. Once again, opfor began to find ways to challenge these changes and make our life difficult, which ended up being a double edged sword. With us being mostly satisfied with our attack plan, we began to work on our defense.


River on Gorodok



We knew our defense wouldn’t be nearly as challenging, as the area was favorable to the defenders thanks to the large area, thick forests, and hilly/village terrains available to us. A 360 degree initial setup with some quick movements in response to contact is all we needed to keep the objectives reliably safe. S1 and S3 defended the SE and NE respectively to hold off any direct attacks, while S2 spread out across the entirety of our NW, W, and SW sides to scout and cover and potential long flanks the enemy may have tried. In our preparation this worked out very well as the squads were spread out just enough to cover all approaches, but also close enough together to move and respond to support each other if one squad began to get overwhelmed. With our plans in hand, we readied ourselves for gameday.



On the day of the scrim, we had some last minute replacements that needed to be called in for S3 to fill out some numbers- thankfully we had Sgt. Mortem, Sgt. Gibson, and PFC Logan on hand to do so. PFC Logan especially would come in very handy for the match itself and all three were a welcome addition to the team. Once that was all settled and the match began, we attacked first as is normally the order of things during 29th scrims. This is where the double edged sword of our preparation began to come into play. Squad Ops has a very different play style to the 29th, and although our rough preparation had gotten us to iron out any kinks or challenges we may face in our path, it took our attention away from the rest of the map on the enemy side of the river. Once we arrived at our staging area on our side of the river and the Bradley began shelling it’s objectives, I took a Kornet missile to the face from the enemy BMP while sitting in my command MRAP from a position on the far north side of the map that none of us thought to use in our preparation. This was quite an embarrassing and shocking moment for me personally, but 2Lt. Dahl did a good job of continuing to keep the team’s morale up and progress with the plan. However, The enemy BMP was not done us. After our Bradley destroyed the north objectives as planned, the BMP relocated to the bottom of the cliff that overlooked the river crossing. Nobody saw the BMP before it began to fire, and as a result S1 lost several players during the crossing before our Bradley was able to quickly dispatch the BMP. The team soldiered on and all squads took their initial areas as planned. This is where our lack of diversity in our preparation bit us again. We paused in our push as we normally did to eliminate any remaining contacts in our direct path, as our enemy was usually stacked there. However, Squad Ops had dispersed themselves far and wide on their side of the river and unbeknownst to us our path to the objectives was actually quite open if we had just taken it. This lead to us giving the enemy a chance to reinforce the objective and get behind us as we made our final push, ultimately resulting in our defeat.



Morale was definitely low after that. Murphy’s Law had come into effect hard and everything that could’ve gone wrong, did. Nonetheless, EP4 showed its heart and determination and everyone collectively decided one thing after we collected ourselves for the next round: We are going to win this round. The squads took their places and awaited the enemy. S3 and parts of S2 took contact first on the south side as a much of the enemy team came from there, while one squad attempted to attack from the direct north. T/5 Evarts and T/5 Perez Pantoja had other ideas though as the two of them stopped the southern attack in its tracks and forced Squad Ops to back off after taking several casualties with none inflicted in return. The T/5 duo began to pressure the enemy and follow them back as they moved east and thinning their numbers even further. Simultaneously, PFC Logan encountered the enemy on the north side and landed a frag rocket on the enemy TL very early in the round. This also encouraged the enemy to break off of their initial attack direction and attempt another push from the northwest. Logan would continue to find enemies to land frag rockets on before eventually being overrun at his position. Between the three of them, these players managed to end up killing about half the enemy and stop their initial pushes. This caused them to not have the strength necessary to really make a dent in any of our held positions and the rest of the team was able to prevent the enemy from even getting close to our bunkers housing the objectives.


It was unfortunate that EP4 ended up being the first Easy Co. platoon to really drop a round against an enemy unit during a scrim, however there were some silver linings and lessons to be learned from the experience. EP4 showed its ability to take a difficult round on the chin and come back stronger as well as to outperform the enemy in terms of who had the stronger defense, and who made the most progress on their attack. Lessons were also learned for how to prepare next time to really keep our eyes open to all sorts of possible strategies from the enemy team, as the way Easy Co. plays Squad is not necessarily the only way to play Squad well. We also learned to believe in our plan a bit more and to not hesitate when we have the upper hand in the future. All in all the scrim was a mixed bag of course as a draw is not an ideal result with the enemy. However, EP4 did come out on top in terms of overall performance during each round comparatively speaking and we learned valuable lessons for the future. I am proud of fourth platoon and I look forward to seeing what we can accomplish on our next outing. Squad Ops were worthy opponents and they were a pleasure to interact with on and off of the battlefield. Hopefully we will get a chance to run it back against them in particular, and show them what we have learned.

Written by Sgt. Newton
Edited by Cpl. Tilley and PFC Mrzena

item.title: The Battle of Malaya and Singapore
item.dc:creator: SSgt. Gibson
item.description:
THE BATTLE OF MALAYA AND SINGAPORE

8 DEC 1941 – 15 FEB 1942


Japanese troops clearing streets, Kuala Lumpur, January 1942.

My home country, Singapore, was the site of one of the most significant events in the Pacific War. Before World War Two, Singapore was considered the gem of the British Empire, a “Gibraltar of the East”, and an “impregnable fortress”. On 15 February 1942, these ideas were shattered as myths. A total of 120,000 British and Allied troops were defeated by and surrendered to the Imperial Japanese Army (IJA) which numbered only 70,000. In just three months, the IJA forces swept the entire Malayan peninsula of 700 miles, inflicted decisive defeats on the Allied troops in key battles, and captured Singapore. Prime Minister Winston Churchill reacted to this defeat in anguish, describing it as the “worst disaster” in British military history. His close companions noted that the tragic loss of Singapore in 1942 remained in Churchill’s memory for years to come.

Background

How did this “disaster” happen for the British forces? Before we answer this question, we must first establish the world’s geopolitical situation at the winter of 1941. As the Axis forces in Europe were making huge gains in the Soviet Union, Britain was already at war for two years and in a precarious predicament. It only miraculously avoided disaster at the events of Dunkirk and the Battle of Britain in 1940. Naturally, Home Command was prioritizing Europe and Africa. By December 1941, Southeast Asia had become an increasingly important strategic location for the Japanese; British colonies and dominions in Asia seemed vulnerable due to the changing world situation. Unlike France which capitulated and gave Indochina to the Japanese, in 1941, Britain still owned the colonies in the East – Malaya, Burma, India, and the Gibraltar of the East: Singapore.

Meanwhile, the Japanese in 1941 were bogged down in the war with China since 1937. After taking the vital coastal cities and North China, the Japanese assault could push no further inland, with cumulative casualties. Japan, facing an embargo from the United States and others, needed oil desperately and could only gather it from the Dutch East Indies (today Indonesia), which was still controlled by the Netherlands despite having capitulated. However, weakened British, Dutch and French empires formed opportunities in Southeast Asia.

Malaya and Singapore were strategically important to the Japanese for three reasons. First, Malaya owned half of the world’s rubber plantations and tin mines. Second, the region had a large population of ethnic Chinese people who also formed the majority in Singapore. They were highly supportive of the Kuomintang and contributed significant relief effort to China, additionally boycotting Japanese goods. Capturing the assets of rich overseas Chinese in the region would be beneficial to the Japanese. Third, the geographic location of Singapore, as well as its fortifications, meant possession of it would hold the Straits of Malacca as a springboard to attack the East Indies and defend against British counter attacks from India. Meanwhile, it also meant that the so-called impregnable fortress would be in Japan’s hands, a great boost to the weary civilian population which had seen the country at war since 1937. From a Japanese strategic point of view, Malaya, Singapore, and eventually all of the East Indies were vital lands needed to be taken if the Japanese were to one day win in China.

At the same time, the United States also controlled the Philippines, a large blob in the way of the rich resources of the East Indies. The Japanese military’s perspective was that it was cornered, needing to find a way to solve her suffocating resource and strategic problem, lest it face utter defeat in China and potential loss of its empire. The opportune time came when most of the U.S Pacific Fleet was reported to be docked in Pearl Harbor.


Overall Japanese Pacific plan


Order of Battle


Malaya invasion plan

Unlike popular belief, the Japanese attack on the Pacific was not due to crazed radical militaristic ambition, but was treated as a necessary action for survival. It was a carefully calculated “do or die” step which Imperial Japan had planned for several years. General Headquarters of the Imperial Japanese Army (IJA) made the decision to perform an all-out strike and defeat all opponents in one decisive and planned strike; the U.S Navy would be crippled, out of the way, by losing capital ships in Hawaii. Meanwhile, the Japanese Army would invade key British, Dutch and American-held naval bases and port cities, proceeding onwards to take the rest of the Asian colonies. The “Southern Expeditionary Group” (Nanpogun) was set up with over 1 million personnel for objectives in Southeast Asia. Prior to this, Japanese intelligence had already been active in Malaya and spent years studying the ground. The Japanese set up contacts with local Malays and Indians, whom they attempted to align, foster anti-British sentiments, and, most importantly, gather military information and maps. On 7 December 1941 (8 December in Tokyo), the plan was commenced.

Assigned to invade Malaya and Singapore was the IJA “25th Army”, a total of 70,000 crack troops commanded by General Yamashita Tomoyuki. This included 3 full strength divisions with experience in China, including the elite Imperial Guards Division. Supplementing this was tank regiments which had a total of 400 vehicles, including the Type 95 Ha-Go and Type 97 Chi-ha tanks. The first transports were sent across the sea at night from Saigon and landed on the Northern Malay coast on the morning of 8 December.


Japanese uniform used in 1941, Malaya

The opponents on the Malay Peninsula was the British “Malaya Command” led by General Arthur Percival. This included two Indian divisions, the Australian 8th Division, as well as the 18th British Division, and volunteers from local ethnic Chinese and Malay population: a total force of 120,000 men. Prior to the battle, the British had called about half of these reinforcements only a few months before. Upon news of the Japanese landing at Thailand, more British troops, including the 18th Infantry Division, were rushed to Singapore. However, the British did not possess tanks other than Bren carriers, as the jungles were deemed unsuitable for tanks.


British uniform worn in 1941, Malaya

A significant part of the Japanese plan was to overwhelm the British Air force and Navy. The Japanese had slightly superior aircraft but only used them sparingly in the campaign due to AA defences. Thus, the first step taken on 8 December was also to cripple any resistance from the air which might slow down an invasion. In one day, only 50 out of the 110 Allied aircraft were destroyed in air strikes. The remainder only consisted of old Brewster and Buffalo aircraft and a few Hurricanes.


Sinking of the HMS Prince of Wales and Repulse

Japanese planners knew that the Royal Navy used Singapore as a giant naval base for its power projection in Asia. Since Japan’s navy was mostly deployed in the Pacific, Japanese forces only had one cruiser and some destroyers to escort the convoys, relying on air power to secure the seas.

A key event which spelled the fate of the battle was the sinking of 2 British battleships, which was the bulk of the British Navy in the far east. Upon hearing news of Japanese landings, this was designated Force Z and sent to intercept Japanese troop ships. Unfortunately for the British, there was no air support available, but the risky decision to send them under the guise of poor weather was still made. On December 10th, the troops were spotted by Japanese submarines in the area. Without any form of air cover, the battleships were quickly destroyed by G4M torpedo bombers.


Japanese pilot’s depiction of the event


Torpedo Bomber Mitsubishi G4M1 “Betty”, referred by Japanese as Hamaki/葉巻(Cigar)


Malaya

Before the real battles had even started, the British already lost any real chance of air-naval superiority due to a sudden Japanese strike. On the 8th of December, when Japanese troops landed on the beaches of Kota Bharu in Kelantan, northern Malaya, they were met by some Allied ground troops. Although the defenders managed to destroy two Japanese transport ships and bring down the first wave of troops, the overwhelming numbers of Japanese troops forced the Allies to retreat.


Japanese troops cross a river in Malaya

The British had anticipated a Japanese landward attack and developed a first-strike plan known as Operation Matador. Under the plan, Allied forces would intercept the Japanese forces just over the Thai border, giving the main forces in Malaya time to gather and attack. However, the Allies failed to detect the Japanese landings before they happened, and British High Command calculated that the defenses at the beach would be sufficient. As the beach fell, the Allied troops, as per the plan, were ordered to Jitra, Kedah, to form an inland defense line, an elastic defense plan. The problem was that Japanese troops already crossed the Thai border and entered northwest Malaya with little resistance. The Japanese, having acquired the port of Kota Bahru, was able to acquire bicycles and additional supplies to move quickly down the peninsula and could use ports to disembark most of their main force and tanks from Saigon.


Japanese troops in Kuala Lumpur, January 1942

The defensive line at Jitra was reached by the Japanese on December 13th, only less than a week after the initial landing. This line was difficult to defend due to it crossing a mountain and very close to the Thai border. Allied forces retreated again inland in the Peninisula to the midpoint of Malaya at the Slim River. The Battle of Slim River on January 7th, 1942 was a disaster for the Allies. Of the 5,000 men from the two Indian brigades who had fought in the battle, only 25% survived. Losing Slim River also resulted in the loss of central Malaya to the Japanese, and Allied troops were quickly encircled and overwhelmed. By the end of January, important Malayan cities Penang and Kuala Lumpur were lost. This meant the Allies had to retreat to Johore and set up a defensive line there, the last before Singapore. At Muar, Johore, 4,000 Allied infantry managed to delay the Japanese advance. A major problem was that most of the allied troops were recruits from India and Malayan volunteers, unlike the more well-trained British and Australian troops. At Muar, there was a casualty rate on the Allies at around 70-75%.


Australian 8th Division anti-tank guns destroyed nine tanks in Johor, slowing the Japanese advance by a few days


Singapore
Trying to slow the overwhelmingly rapid Japanese advance, the British blew up the causeway linking Malaysia to Singapore on February 8th. The Japanese simply used the fishing boats and rafts from villages in Malaya to cross at night. Australian troops fought off initial landing attempts while inflicting casualties on the Japanese. However, the Australian troops retreated unnecessarily amidst some confusion of battle, allowing the Japanese to gain a strong foothold at the shore defense installations. Subsequent landings by the Japanese were unopposed. The military situation for the British under Percival worsened. With shortage of food and especially water, along with highly demoralized troops, Percival surrendered his army unconditionally on February 15th.


British surrender in Singapore


Overall course of events in Malayan Campaign


Concluding Thoughts
The British lost this battle disastrously due to three broad reasons. They suffered from lack of counter-intelligence/preparation, lack of air superiority, and mostly, the Japanese advantage of deploying the first strike. Compounding these three reasons was overconfidence of the High Command and making the assumption that tanks could not be used in jungles. Additionally, because they had strong ground intelligence, the Japanese knew British weak points which allowed a decisive first strike. Once the first strike was successfully done, morale was crippled among the confused defending forces, while morale soared among attacking forces.

It is also likely that the British simply did not have enough air equipment or reliable manpower in the Far East due to overextension; priority was placed on the Home Isles and the intense battle ongoing in North Africa. In Commonwealth countries, it is often remembered that of these 120,000 troops, many were sent to the railways of Burma as workers in near-death or deathly conditions. The gruesome details can be found elsewhere.

As a historian writing this in October 2020, I am without doubt that this campaign has affected this region and the world dramatically. Singapore as an English-speaking former colony often uses this story to explain its contemporary Israel-like defense policy, painting a picture of vulnerability using this battle, and justifying conscription of 2 years which I have served. This Israeli-Singapore model is useful for the defense policies and strategies of other small states.

Timeline

7–8 Dec 1941: Japanese attack Pearl Harbor; Japanese troops land in Northern Malaya.
10 Dec 1941: Japanese sink HMS Repulse and Prince of Wales.
19 Dec 1941: Japanese capture Penang.
7 Jan 1942: Battle of Slim River.
11 Jan 1942: Japanese capture Kuala Lumpur.
31 Jan 1942: Last Allied troops cross the Causeway into Singapore.
15 Feb 1942: Fall of Singapore.

Casualties
Allied Casualties
7,531 killed
10,000 wounded
130,000 captured
Japanese Casualties
3,507 killed
6,150 wounded

Written by PFC Tan

item.title: 29th vs. Real Life: The Combat Engineer
item.dc:creator: SSgt. Gibson
item.description:
29th vs. Real Life: The Combat Engineer

An explosion in Squad

I have been pretty vocal in Easy Co. about saying that the combat engineer is the best AIT. Now personal bias aside from my background as a CE, I think that there is one fundamental argument as to why this is the case. The CE is the only infantry based AIT that can engage and kill any target that the player may come across. All other AITs must be in fear of the enemy tanks or IFVs, but not the combat engineer. While the CE still has to be cautious, those vehicles must instead fear the CE, despite being in a vehicle impervious to 90% of the enemy team. In fact, that is a CE’s primary purpose here in the 29th- to kill enemy vehicles. However, this is just combat engineers in the context of drills within the 29th. Given that the 29th is a realism unit based off of the US military, one may wonder, “What do CE’s do in the US Military today?” As it turns out, there is a bit of overlap. However as one might expect, the role of a CE in the real world is quite a different one to the world of the 29th in other aspects.

The coolest thing about being a combat engineer, in my personal experience, is shooting rockets at enemies and having the enemy vehicles or infantry rage at you over Steam for abruptly ending their life in that round. Here in the 29th, a CE’s primary role in drills is to hit targets with rockets. Although unlike other AITs, the combat engineer has more diversity and depth to its role through the use of the sapper. This role expands the CE’s capabilities by granting them access to mines, IEDs, explosive charges, sandbags and razor wire. Similarly in that regard, combat engineers in the real world are also a very diverse MOS. While combat engineers are trained how to use shoulder fired rockets to engage enemies on the battlefield, they are also taught a plethora of other skills to make them more useful on the battlefield than just combat troops.. Whereas 29th CE’s are more focused on the combat aspect of combat engineering, CE’s in the real world are engineers first and combat troops second.

Combat engineers are trained in several different aspects of construction and destruction that is relevant to combat operations. On the construction side of things, a CE has to know how to, well, be a construction worker. One of their responsibilities is constructing what are known as SEA or SWA huts from lumber and plywood the way any civilian carpenter would. These are rudimentary structures that are used for giving troops at a FOB a roof over their head to get out of the elements.. In addition to wooden construction, CE’s are also versed in concrete for construction purposes and airfield repair. While this may not be as glamorous as blowing up vehicles, it is still a critical part of combat operations.

615th Engineer Construction Company, 4th Engineer Battalion, building Somali-style huts for a training area near Dire Dawa, Ethiopia

However, that is not the only type of construction that engineers are trained in. They are COMBAT engineers after all, and that means that combat construction is one of their primary duties. There are much more construction efforts that go on in a battlefield than one might think. Trenches, bunkers, defenses, tank traps, wire obstacles, and whatever needs to be created on the battlefield are all the responsibility of the engineers. It goes without saying that these are some highly important assets to providing safety for friendly forces as well as being a thorn in the side to all types of enemy forces. How these assets are used in real life can be compared to how they are used in Easy Company. While it is the responsibility of the CE’s to create these types of fortifications and obstacles, they work hand in hand with the leadership of the infantry in order to get it done, similar to how the SL’s in Squad are the ones who place the objects down before the rest of the team builds them. It’s more of a tandem effort in the real world as the leadership have a plan and an idea in mind and the CE’s are the ones who make that plan happen, but also advise the leadership on how to best employ said fortifications or obstacles on the specific terrain they may find themselves in. Also much like Squad, the common rifleman is not left out of the loop. Riflemen have shovels, and in the time-sensitive environment of a combat zone the extra e-tools are always needed for assistance. The key difference here though, is that the CE’s are not limited to using the sandbags and wire that we see in-game. Their capabilities in that regard go all the way up to the emplacement level and even in reshaping the earth around them.

There is one construction effort that CE’s in the real world handle that does not exist in the 29th, and that is bridging. Bridging is one of the tasks that combat engineers take care of that is truly independent from aid or overlap from the infantry. Bringing armored vehicles as well as supplies over a gap in the earth is a critical need for any combat operation to succeed. Rivers, canyons, and rough terrain are everywhere on Earth, and they must not stand in the way of the combat troops. To tackle this, the US military has invented an ingenious alloy of aluminum, magnesium, nickel and a few other metals that works as a super lightweight, flexible and strong material that is fabricated into more or less a giant set of legos made for bridging gaps from a friendly near side without needing a presence on the far side. Combat engineers often take pride in being able to bridge any gap they come across in hours with their giant lego sets, and it is quite a sight to see when they do.

US Soldiers deploying an Improved Ribbon Bridge

However. construction is not all that CE’s are capable of. Oh no, in fact, where a combat engineer truly shines is destruction. You need a bridge blown up?Call the engineers. Do you need a building levelled? Engineers got your back. Do you need a 40ft crater blown into a road? Engineers. While infantrymen do use breaching charges and the like to open doors, CE’s are truly the kings of explosives on the battlefield. While in Squad a CE really only has a stick of C4 and maybe an IED at his disposal, the explosive kit of a combat engineer in the real world is vast and versatile. There are quite a number of different types of explosives used. From high explosives like C4 used to cut metal structures or breach into buildings, to low explosives like ANFO for moving earth and creating obstacles, as well as a whole host of other explosives for different purposes. CE’s are also trained to use explosives in some more nefarious ways that you may associate with the irregular factions in-game such as creating booby traps. However, on the flip side of this, CE’s are also trained in recognizing and eliminating booby traps and other types of hidden explosives like IEDs and mines. Some of these techniques are very creative. For example, there are a few ways to clear a minefield ranging from rolling up your sleeves and poking into the ground with a metal stick to locate mines (yes this is real), to using a metal detector to search for mines and IEDs (also real), to using a string of C4 attached like a chain to the back of a rocket to clear a line through a minefield. When it comes to IEDs, combat engineers tend to steer clear, as they are often much more complicated to deal with. Instead, CE’s do the reasonable thing and let those crazy fools in EOD have a crack at getting rid of the IEDs.

Combat Engineers set explosives to breach obstacles during training on the Korean Peninsula

When you look at it in totality, the combat engineers of the real world and of the 29th do share a lot in common. Although, CE’s in the military are a lot more engineer than combat, and CE’s in the 29th are a lot more combat than engineer. However, their overall purposes are similar when applied to their separate worlds. The brave men and women that serve as combat engineers in the U.S. military today are much like ours here in the 29th, only more so, in that 29th CE’s are a bit of a snapshot or microcosm of the ones stationed around the world.

Written by Sgt. Newton
Edited by Cpl. Tilley and PFC Mrzena

item.title: The Real Life Counterparts to RS2: Vietnam - ARVN, USAF, & AUS
item.dc:creator: SSgt. Gibson
item.description:
The Real Life Counterparts to RS2: Vietnam - ARVN, USAF, & AUS



Despite being represented by three nations, the forces of South Vietnam have a lower weapon variety than that of the North Vietnamese. For the U.S. Armed Forces, Australian Army, and Army of the Republic of Vietnam, a large proportion of the weapons available in RS2 are of American origin. However, there is a juxtaposition found in the American relics from WW2 used by the ARVN with the most modern armaments available to the U.S.

M14

Replacing the iconic M1 Garand as the standard-issue rifle in 1958, the M14 rifle was the final battle rifle issued in mass service to American forces. While the M1 Garand was among the most advanced rifles in its time, by the waning months of WW2, modifications were already being made to the design. Among these modifications included the implementation of automatic fire, box magazines to include additional bullets, and redesigns of gas ports and regulators for better functionality in extreme conditions.

Seeing service in Vietnam for a period of around eight years, the M14 performed adequately; the weapon’s full-power cartridges provided massive penetration power and range. However several issues, stemming from the environment, were present. The length and weight of the M14 led to its users being frequently impaired by dense undergrowth, and the wooden stock had a tendency to swell in the heavy moisture, affecting accuracy. Fiberglass stocks were produced to alleviate these concerns, but the weapon was soon replaced by the M16.


Despite no longer being the standard-issue rifle, the M14 remains in limited service throughout the U.S. military, with civilian variants also used for sport. In its Rising Storm 2: Vietnam representation, the M14 has no concerns with accuracy or ergonomics. Although locked to semi-automatic fire, the weapon is capable of one-shot kills and boasts immense stopping power over its M16 alternative.


M16 / M16A1

Ordered as a replacement by direction of Robert McNamara, overpowering objections from U.S. Army officers supporting the M14, the M16 first entered service in 1967. Lightweight, produced with aluminum alloy, and chambered with intermediate cartridges in a world where traditional rifles were forged from wood and iron, the M16 – earning monikers such as “Mattel-16” and “poodle shooter” – was greeted with much derision from its users.


Indeed, the M16 had severe reliability concerns that would soon be amended by the subsequent variant, the M16A1. The weapon had a malfunction rate of two per one thousand rounds fired, which was only exacerbated by the harsh conditions and poor logistics found in the Vietnam War. Three factors primarily led to widespread extraction failures and malfunctions: a change in powder type from testing environments resulted in differing pressure curves, models lacking chrome-plated chambers, and lax maintenance founded on the misconception that the weapon was self-cleaning.

With 80% of soldiers reporting stoppages and anti-war protests gaining fervor, the M16A1 was quickly introduced in 1967. Issued alongside cleaning kits, the M16A1 boasted many modifications that addressed its predecessor’s infamous reliability issues. A 1968 Department of Army report found that the M16A1 found widespread acceptance by U.S. troops in Vietnam, with 85% preferring to carry an M16 or its carbine-length variant, the XM177E2.

In RS2:V, the M16A1 variant is available. In real life, out of concerns for magazine feed failures, 20-round magazines used in the M16 were not fully loaded, which is also represented in-game as selected historical accuracy. While the M16A1 comes with 20-round magazines, prior to Late War, the maximum capacity in game is 18+1. Authentic to real-life, the M16A1 features low recoil characteristics and provides the player with more ammunition than is available to a M14 user.

M60

Adopted in 1957 and issued beginning in 1959, the M60 has served with every branch of the U.S. military. Seeking to address disparities in suppressive firepower from WW2, particularly in those present against German doctrines, post-war America began a search in the late 1940s for a new, lighter machine gun. Partially derived from German machine guns of WW2, early prototypes of the M60 conglomerated many design principles from the firearms available at the time. Incorporating a semi bullpup system from the FG 42 with the belt feed system from the MG 42, the T161 system was born. Tests and revisions – including the demand to adopt the new NATO standard 7.62mm – led to the final T161E3. Both out of a desire to avoid licensing fees and bias towards domestic products, the U.S. Army adopted the T161E3 over foreign competitors, designating it the “M60”.

While versatile, capable of firing shoulder-mounted, vehicle-mounted, on a tripod, or on a bipod, not even the M60 was invulnerable to the harsh climates of Vietnam. Critical parts of the weapon wore out quickly, and the weapon’s light weight rendered it fragile to damage. As a result of the weapon's volume of fire with the humidity and mud of the environment, diligent maintenance was necessitated. Despite the weapon’s weight and ammunition consumption, the M60 boasted a mixed reputation, with many period American forces appreciating the weapon’s capacity to provide overpowering suppressive fire. Alongside the new M16, the M60 became a familiar sight in wartime photography and post-war cinema, owing to the weapon’s distinctive silhouette.


In RS2:V, the M60 is available with a choice between either 100-round box magazines or a 200-round belt. With the weapon’s voracious appetite, many users opt for the 200-round belt to maximize the weapon’s uptime.

L1A1/L2A1

Widely adopted by many NATO countries, the FN FAL entered service in 1954 with the Australian Army under the designation “L1A1”. To provide common operational and administrative procedures for ease of logistics and communication, the NATO states produced many Standardization Agreements, STANAG for short. As part of the standardization effort, the FAL had select-fire capability, removable magazines, and self-loading function regardless of ammunition. Originally designed to fire intermediate rounds, inspired by the German Strumgewehr, the prime contender was the experimental .280 British, a highly capable caliber balancing weight and rifle-grade ballistics. Early developments of the FAL were forced to abandon this cartridge to appeal to the Americans, who demanded a munition no smaller than .30 calibre. For this reason, the early model T48 rifle, chambered in the 7.62mm NATO cartridge, was developed, although the U.S. eventually dropped the FAL in favor of the M14.

However, from its first production in 1953, the FAL was adopted by over 90 countries and throughout NATO states. The FAL is among the most produced firearms in history. During the Vietnam War, the L1A1 SLR was the standard-issue rifle for the Australian Army. Citing better reliability and higher stopping power, Australian forces greatly preferred their larger caliber weapon over the American M16. With great experience in jungle warfare, owing to earlier conflicts, the Australian forces considered the strengths and weaknesses of the L1A1 and its larger caliber more appropriate with their tactics and doctrine.


In coordination with Canada, Australia developed the L2A1 as a variant to serve as an automatic rifle in a support role. Differences in the design included a heavy barrel, a different front sight, a handguard that also served as a foldable bipod, and unique 30-round magazines. This variant was only used by Canadian and Australian forces, as Commonwealth states primarily used the Bren light machine gun for the support role. As the Bren had changeable barrels and a greater weight, many considered the Bren to be superior for fire support.

Regardless, towards the end of the 20th century, the benefits of intermediate cartridges became increasingly well-known. In comparison to more modern assault rifles, the FAL was too long, too heavy, and too limiting. As years progressed, this weapon designed for universal use was itself replaced. The Belgians adopted the FNC, the Austrians the AUG, the British the L85 – all of which were chambered in the intermediate 5.56mm NATO.

In RS2:V, a stark contrast to the dichotomy between the M14 and the M16, the L1A1 combines the best of both worlds – superior stopping power alongside very serviceable recoil.

Written by Cpl. J. Lee
